section.para:
An is a data structure consisting of two fields: a of elements and the size of that . These fields are structured as a binary whose first element is the size and whose second element is the of elements contained in the . For example,
(3, (a, b, c))
is an containing three elements, a, b, and c.

The primary strength of is that they store their own size. Because of this, access to elements does not require the size as it does for in C (prior to C99) and C++. This allows macro arguments to be variable in size and allows those sizes to change without the user explicitly having to keep track of the size independently.
Like , provide random access to their contained elements.

In C (prior to C99) and C++, can contain only up to elements. In C99, can contain up to elements, but random access to the contained elements is still provided only for elements with indices ranging from 0 to - 1. (Several other -specific primitives--such as --are also limited in this way.)

cannot contain elements with any arity other than unary even in C99. However, they can contain nested or other data structures that contain multiple elements. For example, the following is an of :
(2, ((a, b, c), (x, y, z)))
The -specific primitives are located in the chaos/preprocessor/array subdirectory.
